reviewText: Its great to see two big stars together in a movie although they dont always when together make the best of films,but in this case that's not the case. These types of sex farces at which the 60's was famous,many of which are not very good,in this case it is quite good. Tony curtis became famous for a series of dramatic films in the 50's becoming a hearthrob of sorts to many woman,Houdini about the magician is still entertaining as well as Some like it hot with marilyn monroe. Then in the 60's he decided to concentrate on a series of sex farce type films from the male's perspective which are not always viewed that well today. This is the exception. Jerry lewis started out nightclubbing with dean martin and then taking their routine to movies however the movieswere produced and written to portray his various talents,especially the directing. He eventually split from Martin and went solo. For many years he made solo productions(producer-director-writer) as well as films with mentor frank tashlin,who also directed some of bob hope's best films. He was always with Paramount studios,and this 1965 production is the last film he made with the studio. More on that later. The film works based on a good play,which always helps and Lewis is not used to,nor the adult theme and perhaps theadult fare and costarring with Curtis appealed to him. The dialogue is good it is well directed not degenerating into physicalness or exhibitionism,and remains at the dialogue level. The dialogue is crisp,fresh,whimsical andentertaining and keeps you interested. The film is told from the male perspective and the females are not that bright,but it is told from themales point of view,its that kind of film. The film is a Curtis vehicle,and a european type play about americansd in paris keeping a rotating group of stewerdesses at his apartment,keeping each in the dark,as the curtis sais a'polygamous' romp,but he admits this is a day when marriage is not working. As the Lewis character sais where are the morals today. This is the basis of the movie and thelma Ritter adds much to the film,and is delightful,adding much to a film which good character actresses always do,she steals all her scenes and maybe because she's the female more fleshed out. Lewis seems quite restrainedand the slapstick fairly gone and is low key. The film was a box office flop and i dont know if it was the european setting or what..Lewis next wanted tomake three on a couch(1966)which he made at columbia about a similar typeof person this time with a psychiatrist along but paramount refused andcolumbia took him up and he worked there for a few years. That film was popular with audiences but lambasted with critics. Curtis really ruined his career by making these sexual type farces comedies too often,,Lewis understood thechanging nature of american cinema. At this time it was changing and his audience could no longer be relied on so he changed to a more mature audience and theme but it never really caught on. He saw himself as a filmmaker like chaplin a total filmmaker,but had little critical acceptance in america, morewell thought of in europe by some in high esteem. He is  a different filmmaker and original,and the Tashlin directed movies are quite different than whenhe's in control...which are better? Of course every movies different but some of the films where he plays several disguises you seldom see done today,and children and adults could easily enjoy fare like the Family Jewells(1965)...he's also quite a good standup comedian and was a headliner at nightclubs for much of his career although on variety programs never found hisniche.

reviewText: This is a really funny comedy from the late fifties or early 60's, I can't remember.  Both men are acquaintances and newspaper men in foreign capitals.  Tony Curtis is in Paris and is dating 3 airline stewardesses as fiances, when Jerry Lewis shows up to complicate matters.  New jet engines further complicate things by altering the timetables making it impossible for Curtis to keep his fiances apart.  Lufthansa, British United, and Air France are on a collision course and hilarity ensues.  The final scene has both Curtis and Lewis escaping in a cab driven by a beautiful French girl, one of 3 cab drivers who naturally are at home at different times.  Boeing Boeing.
summary: Jerry Lewis and Tony Curtis at their best

reviewText: I consider this movie one of the Greatest Comedy in Cinema History! TCurtis, JLewis and the less known but great actress Thelma Ritter simply put a Roller-Coaster movie that keeps you glued and amused from start till  the end. Not many other comedies can do the same. And Jerry Lewis part is  not diminished at all by the others ones. (I'm a real Jerry Lewis fan, but  I don't think that Tony Curtis and Thelma Ritter are nobody in Cinema  History, simply look back.....)  All 3 are Simply Great, the Movie is  Simply unmissible and any Superlative Word available in the Vocabulary can  freely be used!

reviewText: When the opening credits run, and the supporting female cast members `measurements' are shown beneath their names, you have no doubt you're in the 60's, bedroom farce, defined. In a roll reversal of sorts Jerry Lewis  plays straight man to Tony Curtis this time around.Bernie Lawrence  (Curtis) is an American newspaper man stationed in Paris, the man for whom  there is never too many airline hostesses, just too little time. His  delicately balanced, and timed to the minute, 4-way love life comes totally  unwound when old pal Robert Reed (Lewis) arrives for an unexpected  stay.Cliché after cliché, time stamped in most every shot, Boeing Boeing  is a tribute to a different type of filmmaking than we see today, a  different morality, a different approach to comedy.Wonderful Paris  sights are an added treat. Recommended.
summary: Jerry Lewis plays it straight to Tony Curtis.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Lewis and Curtis are a dynamic duo!  Curtis plays the likable yet caddish ladies man who juggles three lovely airline hostesses (or attendants if you prefer).  When his long-time friend, Lewis has a layover, he stops by to catch up not knowing the wild ride on which is he is about to embark!Convinced by Curtis to help deceive his three into thinking there the only one, Lewis is soon in over his head along with the aid of Curtis's beleaguered housekeeper played by the incomparable Thelma Ritter -- an archetype for which she probably deserves a great deal of credit.Sit back, buckle up, and get ready for a wild, fabulous ride!
summary: Flight: Non-Stop to Zany, Wonderful Insanity

reviewText: Funny... funny.... funny. This is one of those movies that you never get tired of watching. Ritter is fantastic as the maid... and the story is just great. I actually think this is one Lewis's better parts... he's not silly... he's funny. The girls are gorgeous and feed the fantasy of that time when we all looked at Stewardess's as the most desirable and beautiful women you could find. Obviously  it's not like that now (Just strange men and hags). It's a typical Tony Curtis vehicle in many ways, I mean as a situational comedy. If you're wonder whether or not to buy it, I'll say go ahead, you will not be disappointed at all.

reviewText: Those who have eagerly awaited some of Jerry Lewis' post-Dean Martin classics being released on DVD and Blu-ray for the first time will have a special Valentine courtesy of Olive Films as 1958's "The Geisha Boy," 1958's "Rock-a-Bye Baby" and 1965's "Boeing Boeing" get a 2/14/12 release.  It's hard to imagine that these films have not been made available on DVD prior to now!  Of course, Lewis still remains a love it or loathe it proposition for many modern era film goers--but there is no denying his legacy and impact on the contemporary comedy scene.  Oftentimes content to play the fool, Lewis displayed an innocent appeal on-screen that engaged a sense of silliness in us all.  But he had genuine heart too, and his good-natured screen persona created some indelibly beloved characters that stand in contrast to his more complicated personal life.  These films are an interesting cross section of Lewis' film catalogue as we see him doing what he does best but bringing additional elements of seriousness to the table.  Made of a certain time and place, these films offer great nostalgia value for those that love Lewis--but also an opportunity for new viewers to discover Lewis in his prime."Boeing Boeing" is a real product of its time (despite its 2008 all-star Broadway revival).  Originally penned as a French farce by Marc Camoletti, this play was first adapted for an English language audience in 1962.  It must have seemed like a great idea to bring this broad comedy to the big screen, and its frantic energy is infectious and also a bit tiring.  Tony Curtis is the actual lead who is juggling three live-in fiances.  Seem impossible?  Not when all three are stewardesses for rival international airlines whose schedules never intersect.  But that's all about to change as advances in aviation have created faster jets which upsets Curtis' precise scheduling.  In one harried evening, all three ladies will overlap with Curtis, his put-upon housekeeper (always great to see Thelma Ritter), and Jerry Lewis as Curtis' friend/nemesis who wants in on the action.  It's non-stop mayhem with near misses and constant scheming.  It's all so chaste and silly and perfectly exemplifies the swinging sixties mentality with an undercurrent of sexism as the women are little more than a prize for Curtis' womanizing philanderer.But given all that, it can still be a bit of wacky fun.  Curtis has rarely had such a physically demanding role--he's always on the go.  In a change of pace, Lewis is actually more of the straight guy in the comic piece.  Funny and adult, without his usual cartoonish mannerisms, this actually netted Lewis his only Golden Globe nomination for Best Actor in a Comedy.  The actresses all imbue their cultural stereotypes with enthusiasm (one is British, one French, one German) and Ritter can do no wrong.  I think it's fascinating that Lewis turns in one of his most understated roles in this completely over-the-top scenario!  But it is Curtis, and his constant scrambling, that I always remember.  It's fun and funny, as long as you can just accept the premise at face value.  I always describe this one to people as an extended version of Three's Company with Curtis perfecting the role of Jack Tripper.  Not deep, but energetic and amusing, it's a comedy that succeeds because everyone is fully committed to the silliness.  KGHarris, 12/11.
summary: Swinging Sixties Slapstick And Sexism Offers Jerry Lewis In One Of His More Adult Comic Roles

reviewText: Jerry Lewis is actually, for the most part, playing a straight role instead of the comedic relief.  The interactions between the cast members is pretty good, and they seem to "click".  I remember seeing this movie years ago but don't remember seeing the eyebrows on Tony Curtis looking like someone went crazy with an eyebrow pencil!  For a man, in some scenes it looks like he's wearing too much make-up.  And another thing I don't remember is one of the women bouncing around in a towel.  And I do mean bouncing.  It was a small towel as well, as there were some rather interesting glimpses of the woman's backside.  But still, a good movie considering the time it was made, and is about three women living with a guy - but sleeping in different bedrooms.

reviewText: This was always one of the funniest classic comedies that I grew up with. Tony Curtis is a playboy in France who has three air line attendants for fiance. With each girl  from a different air line things have worked out for him. Worked out until all three girls show up in town at the same time because of them being transferred to a new airline causing comedy confusion as Tony exists his buddy Jerry Lewis to help keep the girls apart. Jerry has a back stabbing scheme of his own for this arrangement.

reviewText: I remember seeing this film as a kid with my Dad ;) We both enjoyed it then. I remember my old man saying "It was ALMOST a Dean Martin & Jerry Lewis movie" I thought that Curtis & Lewis should have worked on at least three more films together. "SIGH" Ahh, but at least we have this fun romp to enjoy. Oh man were the women in this flick hot or what? Yeah Baby! Now isn't that kinda cool in a swinging sixties way?

reviewText: This was a funny movie and who ever picked Jerry Lewis and Tony Curtis to star in it knew what they were doing. They made a great team in making this movie what it is. The only problem is as the years go by I don't find people running around naked with a towel wrapped around them and what it suggests from my point of view. Some people would call me a prude or old fashioned to think this way but I don't care if people think that. I don't think I would suggest to a friend that they buy this movie because there were other instances in the movie as well that gives an impression I don't like such as loose living which is all the rage today.
